I heavily regret letting the weird name and the art put me off this game. I didn't play Portia for the same reason. 

This game has taken over my life. It's a little overwhelming until you get the hang of things but it's so worth it.

I was a huge fan of the first game, even though My Time at Portia felt a bit unpolished. The graphics and animations were a little ugly and the game itself could be glitchy, but the storytelling and mechanics were so good that I could overlook those things.

This game blows My Time at Portia out of the water. The game has arguably more polish (I can now have long hair that blows in the wind), the mechanics are more in depth, and the lore continues to expand. The characters are just as in depth as the ones from the original title and little references to the first game make this world feel even more alive. All of this to say: Pathea's writing team deserves a raise, the storytelling in the My Time series is incredible. 

And the soundtrack. Oh my god. You could tell me the Sandstorm soundtrack was from Red Dead 2 and I'd believe you. 

I've grown to love the art style, and I'm not sure about how I feel about them changing it so drastically for Evershine. The only thing I have to complain about is the fact that not all of the dialogue is voice acted, which kind of does break my immersion and removes some of that polish.

But overall, I love this game and I'd definitely recommend it :)

My Time at Sandrock is a charming and surprisingly deep game that kept me hooked from the start. The cast is easily one of the strongest parts of the game, with a wide variety of characters who all feel distinct in design, personality and backstory. The main story is lengthy and engaging, especially the whole ordeal with Logan and his gang. I also enjoyed the freedom to customise the workshop and house in any shape or style I wanted, but the camera in Edit mode needs some work. Also, the machines pulls items from both our chests and inventory, which is one of my favourite features in crafting games like this. 

However, the game could use many quality of life fixes, as certain resources require heavy grinding, mounts sometimes get stuck in awkward spots, and the factory does not clearly display required materials for large blueprints. My biggest issue was the save system, which occasionally failed to store progress properly. More than once I loaded the game only to find hours of progress missing, and I am far from alone in having that problem. Voice acting quality is mixed, with some lines sounding stiff or grating, and cutscenes often rush through dialogue at an unnatural pace. Game performance can also dip noticeably with lag and stuttering, especially in late game, even on stronger PCs.

Despite the flaws, I still had a great time with My Time at Sandrock. I will definitely be keeping an eye out for the developers‚Äô next title, My Time at Evershine.

This game has a -lot- of issues, but none of those issues are a major obstacle to the fun factor. If you want to play Stardew Valley in 3D, this is the game for you.

Good:

‚Ä¢ Good and long story
‚Ä¢ Endearing three-dimensional NPCs
‚Ä¢ Satisfying gathering and crafting systems
‚Ä¢ Lots of content (every time you've reached the end, the map expands again, and again)
‚Ä¢ The game has a quicksave key. This is amazing, especially in regards to mitigating the impact of certain game-breaking bugs (see below).
‚Ä¢ The voice acting (at least the English VAs) is amazing, for the most part. And there are a -lot- of recorded lines.

Neutral:

‚Ä¢ Stamina. Like other games of this type, stamina is required for all actions and only regenerates when you go to sleep. This system is necessary for the game to work, but it's not flawless. For instance, I dislike the fact that combat also costs stamina, in a game where enemies linger around most gathering nodes (meaning you have to choose between either killing the enemies and wasting stamina, or tanking unnecessary hits).
‚Ä¢ The character creator is okay, but not amazing. You have free RGB selection of skin and hair colour, but you can only choose from a set of preset faces without any real facial feature fine-tuning possible afterwards. I also find the hairstyles a bit lacking, but that's subjective.
‚Ä¢ The music is okay. Not a soundtrack I'd listen to outside of the game though.
‚Ä¢ I found the clothing choices somewhat lacking, but that's of course also subjective. The game does have a severe and disturbing lack of black and purple clothes though.

Bad:

‚Ä¢ Bugs. This game has more bugs than any game I've played in recent years (and some of them are quite game-breaking, like broken cutscenes, vanishing NPCs or NPCs that teleport into the sky and are now uninteractable, or outright softlocks as something doesn't load right).
‚Ä¢ The performance is not great. The more moving pieces are in the scene, the worse it gets. This also means that the game really struggles if you expand and decorate your workshop to its maximum potential.
‚Ä¢ Combat. I was personally not a fan of it. More tedious than anything. There is no depth at all with each weapon type only having a 5-hit key-mash combo, but that part's to be expected in a game like this. But each weapon animation also leaves you completely immobile during the animation (think: Monster Hunter), which is very frustrating in a game where the enemies are constantly moving around while you're fighting them.
‚Ä¢ The progression feels a bit "off". In the early game you'll never have enough stamina to gather all the resources you need for missions; by endgame you'll have more resources than you'll know what to do with and will be going to bed with a full stamina bar most days, since there's just nothing you can productively spend it on anymore. I would have preferred it if the early game items/commissions cost less resources to make and the late game items/commissions cost considerably more resources to make to balance the stamina consumption a bit better. This is, all things considered, a minor gripe though.
‚Ä¢ Commissions (your main way of earning money) are extremely tedious to do. A commission is a villager asking you to build something. They do this by putting up a commission on the commission board. You accept the commission there and then you build the items they want, but in order to actually complete commission, you have to go find and talk to that villager directly. This is extremely frustrating, as (as mentioned above) NPCs randomly teleport across the map or just vanish from the map entirely; alternatively your machines just take too long to make the necessary items and the NPC has gone to bed by then, locking the doors and making the commission not completable on that day (which nets a penalty compared to same-day deliveries). Not to mention that every house, including your own, are a separate instance, separated by a loading screen, so if you have to deliver 4 items to 4 different NPCs in 4 different houses, you have to sit through at least 7 loading screens just to complete those commissions every day.
I put way more hours into this game than I expected. Looking forward to the next game.

Very fun game if you enjoy things in the Harvest Moon/Stardew Valley genre.  It‚Äôs a 3D action adventure format instead of a top-down 2D and has a focus on resource gathering and crafting instead of farming but otherwise shares a lot of elements.  Time progression focusing on day to day with a larger calendar with seasons, special events, and social aspects with various townsfolk including marriage/kids.  Progression systems related to gathering, crafting, combat, and social game aspects.  It also has a more well defined story than something like Stardew Valley; there is a central questline which a lot of areas and content tend to be gated by in addition to the normal tiers of tools and resource nodes locked behind better tools progression.

I also really enjoy the setting.  It‚Äôs set well into the recovery period after an apocalypse of some kind so you get to have the developing frontier town feeling but with some amount of recovered technology and steampunk-ish flavor.  Something about the optimistic tone you usually have in life/social sim game in the Stardew Valley genre pairs adds a nice balance to the struggle of rebuilding civilization after an apocalypse.  It‚Äôs interesting having some of the resource nodes be things like plastic remnant or metal scrap you can recycle into usable materials.  The dungeons are often decaying old-world ruins like a derelict shopping mall or the decaying office buildings.

There are absolutely fantastic quality of life features over any other game in this genre, not tying saving to the end of day sleep and a the slider which changes the in-game passage of time vs. real-world passage of time.  I‚Äôve played Stardew Valley in a way where I‚Äôll path through areas to see where I needed go and then restart, sometimes multiple times when something doesn‚Äôt go well or I forget to do something before the time window closes.  This allows saves at any time which is great both to check on small things without having to restart an entire day, or just being able to quit at any time without having to either finish everything or abandon the rest of the usable time in that day.  Being able to set time progression to 60% makes me feel less rushed and more likely to get everything I feel I need to do done in a day.

I think the most negative thing about it is that it is a pretty big time sink.  I played 200 hours of Stardew Valley and 150 hours of My Time at Portia and I‚Äôll probably clock a similar amount in this one.  Overall, it‚Äôs a fantastic game in the genre.

My playtime on MTASR alone should indicate my love for this game.

What Works

Crafting & commissions: Crafting feels streamlined, with machines that can be queued and materials pulled from storage, making commissions satisfying and efficient.

Desert survival layer: Scarce water and resources add a layer of planning and strategy to daily routines, keeping gameplay engaging.

Quality-of-life improvements: Saving at any time allows for experimentation without concern for losing progress.

Social systems: Interactions with characters feel meaningful, with quests and relationship options that make connections rewarding.

Ruins exploration: Abandoned ruins are engaging, with varied designs and challenges that make each expedition enjoyable.

What Falls Short

Performance issues: Occasional pop-ins and texture glitches can be distracting.

Repetitive: After completing multiple quests and fighting mobs, the gameplay feels repetitive. 

Compared to its predecessor,  My Time At Portia, Sandrock is more polished and strategic, with smoother crafting, exploration, and social systems. Despite minor performance and animation issues, it provides a satisfying and immersive life-sim experience.
